Rainfall EDA - Iteration 1

Exploratory Data Analysis on Rainfall

The purpose of this page is to explore the trends in one of the predictor variables the solar exposure, we believe this variable impacts pedestrian count which our client intends to make appropriate decisions to promote. The cumulative amount of solar energy that falls on a horizontal surface is referred to as the global solar exposure. Daily global sun exposure is the cumulative amount of solar energy received during a single day. Regular global exposure levels are usually between 1 and 35MJ/m2 (megajoules per square metre). For mid-latitudes, values are typically higher during summer's bright sun and lowest during winter or very cloudy days. The Dataset was sourced from the bureau of metrology website. The data from BOM website ranges from 1990 to date however we are only considering a subset of the dataset from 2015 to date as one of our predictor variables.

Activity Visual(s) Comments
Datasets inspect
    - The rainfall dataset date is range from 2015-01-01 to 2021-02-28. The rainfall amount with mean 1.51 millimetres.
    - The rainfall amount is range from 54 to 0 (max and min).
    - The median is less than mean, the dataset is skewed to the right, most of data spread on the right side
    - The total of rainfall amount on Saturday is largest, while rainfall amount on Wednesday is lowest
    - If check the error, the difference between Saturday and other day of week is significant.
    - The days of week (except Saturday) are not significant.
    - The Feb and Mar are significant from rest of month.
    - It was particularly wet in April; averaged across all reporting sites in Greater Melbourne, it was the wettest April since 1974.
    - There are a lot of outliers in rainfall dataset, resulting in missing fit the rainfall trend. The R square is relatively low.
    - The KNN fit rainfall best among these five models
